abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Clinical chatbots are increasingly used to help integrate genetic testing into clinical contexts, but no chatbot exists for <jats:italic>A</jats:italic><jats:italic>polipoprotein</jats:italic> L1 (<jats:italic>APOL1</jats:italic>) genetic testing of living kidney donor (LKD) candidates of African ancestry. Our study aimed to culturally adapt and assess perceptions of the Gia® chatbot to help integrate <jats:italic>APOL1</jats:italic> testing into LKD evaluation. Ten focus groups and post-focus group surveys were conducted with 54 LKDs, community members, and kidney transplant recipients of African ancestry. Data were analyzed through thematic analysis and descriptive statistics. Key themes about making Gia culturally targeted included ensuring: (1) transparency by providing Black LKDs’ testimonials, explaining patient privacy and confidentiality protections, and explaining how genetic testing can help LKD evaluation; (2) content is informative by educating Black LKDs about <jats:italic>APOL1</jats:italic> testing instead of aiming to convince them to undergo testing, presenting statistics, and describing how genetic discrimination is legally prevented; and (3) content avoids stigma about living donation in the Black community. Most agreed Gia was neutral and unbiased (82%), trustworthy (82%), and words, phrases, and expressions were familiar to the intended audience (85%). Our culturally adapted <jats:italic>APOL1</jats:italic> Gia chatbot was well regarded. Future research should assess how this chatbot could supplement provider discussion prior to genetic testing to scale <jats:italic>APOL1</jats:italic> counseling and testing for LKD candidate clinical evaluation.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: All procedures followed were in accordance with the ethical standards of the responsible committee on human experimentation (institutional and national) and with the Helsinki Declaration of 1975, as revised in 2000 (5). The study was approved by the Institutional Review Boards at Northwestern University (STU00214038) and Georgetown University (STUDY00003752). Northwestern University served as the Institutional Review Board of record. Informed consent was obtained from all participants as required by the IRB, prior to participation in the study. Individual-level (survey) data were analyzed in aggregate; all data were de-identified. This research adheres to the principles set out in the Declaration of Helsinki.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Informed consent was obtained from all individual participants included in the study. Participants gave their informed consent for their data to be published in aggregate.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare no competing interests.

group.label: Declaration of AI and AI-assisted technologies in the writing process.
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Absolutely no form of Generative Artificial Intelligence was used in the scientific writing of this manuscript.
